name: mukkuri
definition: Mukkuri is a traditional Japanese plucked instrument, part of lamellophone family, being indigenous to the Ainu people.
description:
The Mukkuri is made from wood of bamboo and is 10 cm long and 1.5 cm wide.

It is an indigenous instrument to the Ainu people of northern Japan - Hokkaido.

Mukkuri is similar to Jew's harp but is made of wood and does not know the same wide spread.

The Mukkuri's vibrating tongue is attached to a string which is pulled sideward, away from the musician's head.

The sound is produced by manipulating the string, and while the instrument is unpitched, tone manipulation can be accomplished by altering the size of musicianâ€™s mouth, which serves as a resonance box during playing.

Traditionally played by women, Mukkuri are quite difficult to sound due to their very thick tongue, and require some practice.

Mukkuri is often accompanied with Tonkori, a plucked string instrument.

Mukkuri are now sold in Japan as tourist items.
